column2: VARDESC
Which of the following best describes the source of test gas?
Which of the following best describes the source of test gas? Other
Which of the following best describes the method for measuring inspired and expired volumes over time?
Which of the following best describes the method for measuring inspired and expired volumes over time? Other
Regardless of the method being used, does the device maintain the required volume accuracy, regardless of the gas mixture, direction of gas flow (e.g. inhaled or exhaled), or pulsatile flow pattern?

Is the device calibrated to accurately detect the exhaled carbon monoxide and the tracer gas concentrations, which is calculated between the inhaled (test gas concentrations) and zero measurement (no CO or tracer gas present in the device)?

If so, are the deviations from the true measurement within 0.5% of the full scale? (for example, if 0.3% CO is used for the test gas, then the maximum error on any dilution should be no more than +/- 0.0015%)
What is the measured gas concentration at zero?
What is the gas concentration of the test gas?
What is the measured gas concentration of the test gas?
Is significant drift observed over the time scale of the test (~30 sec)?
Is the reading stable +/- 0.001% absolute for CO?
Is the reading stable +/- 0.5% of the full scale reading for the tracer gas?
Is a demand-flow regulator being used on a compressed test gas cylinder?
If no, is the circuit resistance of the device <1.5 cm*H20/L/s at 6 L/s flow?
If yes, is the circuit resistance of the device <10cm H20 at 6L/s inspiratory flow?
Is the timing device accurate to within 1% (100ms over 10s)?
What timing technique was used for calibration and/or testing?
Does the timing equipment rely on automated data computation?
If so, how accurate is the breath-hold time computation?
What is the dead space volume measurement for the inspired test gas?
How is this metric used in the data-computation above?
What is the dead space volume measurement for the alveolar sample?
How is this metric used in the data-computation above?
For adults, is the dead space volume consisting of the volume from the valve, filter, and mouthpiece under 0.35 Liters?
Within the last week, was the device tested to be leak-free?
Was the volume calibration test with the 3L syringe performed?
Was the calibration test performed with a 'standard subject' (biological control) or simulator?
Within the last 3 months, was the accuracy of the measured gas readings assessed?
If no, what is today's date (test date)?
Was the device tared to zero after the last test?
Did the subject breathe supplemental oxygen for 10 min prior to this test?
Was the subject involved in any exercise prior to this test?
If so, please describe the intensity level of the exercise.
Was the subject in a supine position prior to this test?
If so, please provide the duration of the patient in the supine position?
Has a demonstration of the manuevers involved in the test and instructions been provided to the subject?
What time did the subject smoke his/her last cigarette?
What length of time did the subject need for total exhalation?
If total exhalation time > 4sec, please note the expiratory time in seconds
Is the sample gas volume collected between 0.5-1.0L?
What type of tracer gas was used?
What type of tracer gas was used? Other
Is the inspired CO around 0.3% of the collected volume?
Does the subject have obstructive airway disease?
If so, were at least 10 minutes allowed between tests?
Was a bronchodilator used?
Were at least 4 minutes allowed between tests?
Did the subject remain seated during that interval?
Does the device remove CO2 from the exhaled gas?
Does the device remove H20 from the exhaled gas?
Does the device allow exhaled gases to cool (e.g. volume to contract)?
What is the age of the subject?
What is the sex of the subject?
What is the height of the subject?
What racial/ethnic group does the subject identify with?
Are carboxyhemoglobin levels < 2%? If not, needs to be considered in interpretation
